title-group.article-title: Adaptive pole placement control for vibration control of a smart cantilevered beam in thermal environment

article-meta.aff: State Key Laboratory of Vibration, Shock and Noise, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Ting Zhang, State Key Laboratory of Vibration, Shock and Noise, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, People’s Republic of China Email: ztwcl@sjtu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Piezoelectric actuators used in vibration control and high precision control have been widely used in recent years. In aeronautics and MEMS systems especially, their applications are spread from vibration suppression to position control. In this paper, a finite element model (FEM) of a piezoelectric actuator and cantilever in a thermal environment is presented to suppress vibration effectively. In other words, the FEM is namely a thermal-electrical-mechanical coupled FEM. Based on an eight-node plane finite element, the harmonic analysis and the free vibration analysis have been obtained in the current work. Therefore a transfer function model will be attained through the harmonic analysis by an identification method. In addition, a controller is designed with the adaptive pole placement control (APPC). Finally, through simulation, the thermal influence is considerable for natural frequencies, harmonic response and free vibration. Moreover, the APPC is a significant plan to vibration control in the paper.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Applications of smart materials, such as piezoelectric materials, magnetostrictive materials, magneto-rheological fluids, electro-rheological fluids and shape memory alloys, have been developed increasingly in recent years (Meng et al., 2006; Zhou et al., 2006; Choi., 2008).
However piezoelectric materials can be the most popular smart materials in actuators applications by reason of low power consumption, low weight, and ease in bonding with the structures.

Recently many researchers have devoted themselves to studying the drive capability of piezoelectric materials in adiabatic conditions. Actually, the system composed of piezoelectric materials and the structures always works in a thermal environment, and the system is influenced when the temperature in external surroundings changes. The piezoelectric materials and structures expand with heat and contract with cold; they produce voltage when the temperature value is different in both ends and generate heat when high voltage is applied. So, considering the impact of the heat it must be important for vibration control and high precision control. Therefore, the dynamic model analysis of the influence of the coupling among thermal, electrical and mechanical fields has been visibly presented (Song et al., 2004; Giannopoulos and Vantomme, 2006; Kumar et al., 2008).

There are many methods to model the system’s dynamical model. a finite element formulation for the vibration of piezoceramic laminated plates that takes hysteretic behavior into account is presented (Song et al., 2004; Kusculuoglu and Royston, 2008) the system equations can be derived using Hamilton’s principle and the assumed mode method (Xue and Tang, 2006); the finite element model (FEM) results are validated against measured ones (Vasques and Rodrigues, 2007); a dynamic neural observer is proposed and the neural network weights are adapted on-line, and no off-line learning is required. It is attained by experimental data from the laboratory (Li et al., 2010). This study presents the results of multimodal vibration suppression of a smart flexible cantilever beam with piezoceramic actuator and sensor by suing a pole placement controller (Sethi and Song, 2008); Sethi and Song (2005) put forward subspace identification after acquiring a model frame. Yang et al. (2005) bring forward both an adaptive filter for system identification and the adaptive controller for vibration suppression; the transfer functions are identified with the Steiglitz-McBride iteration method (Herold et al., 2006).

The control laws for vibration suppression vary from one application’s aim to another. it is investigated by a Lyapunov approach that a combined scheme of proportional plus derivative (PD) feedback and command voltages applied to segmented piezoelectric actuators, which are bonded to the surface of the flexible link, can effectively control the rigid body motion and at the same time, damp link vibration (Sun et al., 2004). This paper presents the design and the experimental implementation of fast and periodic output feedback controllers to minimize structural vibration, using collocated piezoelectric actuators and sensors (Ezhilarasi et al., 2006); for designing a robust vibration controller, Jha and Inman (2004) used a sliding mode technique; the vibration suppression and precision positioning capabilities of the adaptive feed-forward control have been discussed (Ma and Ghasemi-Nejhad, 2006); a fuzzy control system is then designed and implemented for vibration suppression of the smart beam subjected to the impulse excitation and resonance disturbances (Doosthoseini et al., 2008); He and Jha (2003) adopt the Generalized predictive control to vibration reduction.

Most recently, although there are many models and many control laws for active control in the literature, a number of researches on the electromechanical coupled analysis of smart structures using finite element theories have been presented. However, the number of publications dealing with the thermal-electrical-mechanical coupling analysis is limited.

Actually considering the impact of the external temperature changing must be urgent for vibration control and high precision control. At the same time, the adaptive control is such that a control system can adjust the parameters or generate a control action. This will enable the system still to run by a performance in the best condition approach, no matter that the outside world is undergoing tremendous changes or that the system is producing uncertainty. In the paper, a cantilevered beam structure bonded with a piezoelectric actuator is always working in a thermal environment, while the temperature in external surroundings is changing and the smart system could be influenced. The mechanical model of a smart system is different constantly with the temperature changing. Accordingly, the dynamic model of a system must be identified in order to design a control law online to control vibration.

Moreover, a proper damping ratio of a system is helpful to suppress vibration, whether or not a velocity feedback control law or a pole placement control law can change the system’s damping ratios to decrease the amplitude of vibration. But sometimes, a velocity signal is not measured by a displacement sensor. Hence, in the paper, an adaptive pole placement control (APPC) with an observer is implemented to restrain vibration.

In this paper, the authors introduce a thermal-electrical-mechanical coupled model using plane finite element formulations and a pole placement control law in the second part. The simulation result of modal analysis, harmonic analysis, free vibration and vibration control are introduced in the third part. Finally, some conclusions and outlooks are derived from simulation result.

sec.title: 2.1. Constitutive linear equations
sec.p:
In the present study, a cantilevered beam structure bonded with a piezoelectric actuator is shown in Figure 1. The beam is always working in a thermal environment, and the external temperature varies continuously. When the piezoelectric actuator is applied with a dynamic voltage (e.g. sinusoidal signal), the beam swings upper and lower at a certain frequency. Then, if the surroundings temperature remains stable, the frequency of the swing stays the same. On the contrary, if the surroundings temperature varies, the frequency of swing is not always the same. Therefore, elastic field, electric field and thermal field for a typical intellectual structure are considered to be linearly coupled. Figure 1.
A cantilevered beam bonded with a piezoelectric actuator.

In ANSYS v13, the element PLANE233 has structural-thermal and thermal-piezoelectric capabilities which are of much interest. The geometry, node locations, and the coordinate system for this element are shown in Figure 2. The element input data includes eight nodes and structural, thermal, and electrical material properties.X Figure 2.
Geometry and coordinate systems for 8-node PLANE223.

The element has eight nodes with up to four degrees-of-freedom per node {ux,uz,V,T} as illustrated in Figure 2. Here, ux and uz are the lateral mid-plane displacement in x and z directions, V is the applied voltage, and T is the temperature rise from the stress free reference temperature. Accordingly, the displacement field equations can be written as equations (1), at the same time, the strain and stress equations should be written as (2) and (3) respectively (Kusculuoglu and Royston, 2008). (1)u1=ux(x,z,t)-zψx(x,z,t)u3=uz(x,z,t) Where ψx(x,z,t)=∂uy(x,z,t)∂x (2){x1=∂ux∂x-z∂ψx∂xX1=c11x1 Where x, X and c represent the mechanical stress, the mechanical strain and the elastic stiffness constant respectively.

Moreover, the purpose of this paper is to develop a new control strategy for vibration suppression of a cantilevered beam using a piezoelectric actuator. So, the linear coupling piezoelectric constitutive equations have been widely used as (3){x1=s11EX1+d31E3D3=d31X1+ɛ33XE3 Where s, d, E, D and ɛ represent elastic compliance constant, piezoelectric stress constant, electric field, electric displacement and free dielectric constant respectively.
We can change equations (3) into (4) (4){X1=c11Dx1-h31D3E3=-h31x1+β33xD3 Where h and β represent piezoelectric stiffness constant and free dielectric isolation rate respectively.

If the thermal influence for structure and piezoelectric actuators is considered, a thermal-electrical- mechanical coupled formulation (equations (5)) is introduced in order to represent direct and converse piezoelectric effects (Giannopoulos and Vantomme, 2006; Kumar et al., 2008). (5){X1=c11Dx1-h31D3-λ1XθE3=-h31x1+β33xD3+p3EθS=-λ1Sx1+p3SD3+αθ Where λ, θ, p, S and α represent the coefficient of thermal expansion, the temperature, the pyroelectric constant, the entropy of the system and the ratio of the heat capacity and the strain free temperature.

sec.title: 2.2. Finite element model
2.2.1. Kinetic energy terms
2.2.2. The elastic, electrical and thermal energy terms
sec.p: The elastic, electrical and thermal energy of the smart structure can be obtained as (9)δEp=∫V(X1δx1+E3δD3+Sδθ)dV=∫V(c11x1δx1 +ɛD3δD3+αθδθ)dV=δ({q}T[Kqq]{q}+φ[Kφq]{q} +θ[Kθq]{q}+φ[Kφφ]φ+θ[Kθφ]φ+θ[Kθθ]θ)

sec.title: 2.2.3. The virtual work term
sec.p: (10)δW=∫0lfδuzdx-∫0lcu·zδuzdx+∫0lVohδφAxdx +∫VQδθdV={Rq}δ{q}+Rφδφ+Rθδθ Where f is the external disturbance, c is the structure damping, Vo is the voltage across the structure, and Q is the heat flux. l, h and V are length, thickness and volume of the smart structure element respectively.

sec.title: 2.2.4. Finite element formulation
sec.p: The system mathematical equations can be derived according to the Hamilton’s principle (equations (11)). (11)δJ({q},φ,θ)=δ∫t0tfL({q},φ,θ;t)dt=∫t0tf(δEk-δEp+δW)dt=0

Considering the resistance R and inductance Lφ of the piezoelectric actuator, Element mass, damp and stiffness matrices for the system can be written as shown in equation (12) by using equations (1) to (11). The equation of motion for a system with a single piezoelectric patch can be constructed: (12)[[M]000Lφ0000][{q··}φ··θ··]+[[C]000R0000][{q·}φ·θ·]+[{Kuu}KuφKuθ{Kφu}KφφKφθ{Kθu}KθφKθθ][{q}φθ]=[{Rq}RφRθ]
And the related scalar, vector and matrix terms from equation (12) are shown in the Appendix (A.1).

sec.title: 3. The adaptive pole placement control law
sec.p: The pole placement control is a feedback control and offers the flexibility relocate the dominated poles of the system in order to achieve the desired performance by selecting the desired poles (Sethi and Song, 2006; Kumar and Khan, 2007). In other words, the vibration of system will be effectively suppressed by selecting desired damping ratios. The transfer function of the beam’s tip displacement and the applied voltage on piezoelectric actuators can be written as: (13)H=∑i=1nb1is+b0is2+2ξiωis+ωi2 Where ωi and ξi are the natural frequency and the damping ratio of the its mode respectively, and b1i and b0i determines the location of the zeros of the transfer function H. The transfer function H can be identified from harmonic analysis data using the MATLAB built in command ‘invfreqs’ (Sethi and Song, 2008).

It is known that the dynamic response of a second order transfer function has no vibration and achieves a stable state in a short time when the damping ratio is 0.707. Therefore the desired poles can be attained when ξi is 0.707 without changing the natural frequency ωi, so transfer function H can be transformed into a continuous time state space representation: (14){{χ·}=[A]{χ}+{I}vy={F}{χ}+Pv Where {χ} and y are the state variable vector and the output tip displacement of the smart beam respectively. [A], {I}, {F} and P present the state matrix coefficient, the input column vector coefficient, the output row vector coefficient and direct transfer coefficient respectively. Here P is zero. The input signal of the feedback controller v can be determined by equation (15) when the state feedback gain vector {K} is obtained by feedback law and desired poles. (15)v=r-{K}{χ}
The matrix ([A]-{I}{K}) determines the eigenvalues of the close loop system (equation (16)) by desired poles in the Ackermann’s method.

However, the full states χ may not be easily achieved in practical situations. Then a state observer must be designed to obtain the entire states of the system. The design of the state observer can be done by the above pole assignment. The dynamical former of the observer is written as: (17)∧·χ=([A]-[G]{F})φ∧+Gy+Iv Where G is observing matrix and is obtained by pole placement technique.

The observer’s state χ∧ will approach asymptotically to the actual state χ when the eigenvalues of the matrix ([A]-{I}{K}) are negative. The temperature of the external environment is always changing, and the thermal-electrical-mechanical model of the systems is always time-varying. The system model and the controller must be identified all the time to maintain the control precision. Accordingly, the APPC system with a observer is attained by equations (16) and (17), shown in Figure 3. Detailed numerical value of the equation (14), gain matrix {K} in the controller and gain matrix {G} in the observer are shown in the Appendix (A.2). Figure 3.
The state feedback system with an observer.

sec.title: 4. Results and discussion
sec.p:
The smart beam system works at a very rugged environment in temperatures from -40∘ to +150∘. There will be thermal-mechanical coupled energy transformation for the beam and the piezoelectric actuator (Song et al., 2004). Moreover, there will be electric-mechanical coupled energy transformation for the piezoelectric actuator so as to actuate the beam when the piezoelectric patch is applied with 100 V voltage. The correlation coefficient from equation (12) is shown in Table 1 (Giannopoulos and Vantomme, 2006; Xue and Tang, 2006; Kumar et al., 2008; Kusculuoglu and Royston, 2008). The coefficients of thermal expansion and thermal conductivity with the temperature are shown in Figure 4 (Xue and Tang, 2006; Kusculuoglu, and Royston, 2008). Figure 4.
(a) The coefficient of thermal expansion (b) The coefficient of thermal conductivity.
Table 1.
System parameters used in simulation
Beam parameters
Lb=0.3m wb=0.04m hb=0.0032m
ρb=7.84×103kg/m3 Yb=2.0×103N/m2 cb=0.01
Piezoelectric parameters
Lp=0.05m wp=0.034m hp=0.00025m
ρp=7.8×103kg/m3 Yp=2.1×103N/m2 vp=0.29
g31=0.775×109N/m2 d31=2.2×10-11C/N d32=0.3×10-11C/N
d33=-3.0×10-11C/N ɛ33=12 p3=-0.25×10-3V/K
xp=0.085m

In Table 1, Lb, wb, hb, ρb, Yb and cb are the length, height, width, density, Young’s modulus and damping of the beam respectively, and Lp, wp, hp, ρp, and Yp are the length, height, width, density, and Young’s modulus of the piezoelectric actuator respectively. vp, g, d, ɛ and p are Poisson’s ratio, electric field stress constant, piezoelectric stress constant, free dielectric constant and pyroelectric constant respectively. xp is the location of the piezoelectric patch on the beam. In Figure 4, (a) and (b) are the curve of the ratio of the heat capacity and the strain free temperature and the coefficient of thermal expansion with temperature changing respectively.

sec.title: 4.1. Harmonic analysis
sec.p: In the harmonic analysis simulation in ANSYS v13, a sinusoidal voltage is loaded on a piezoelectric patch at the thickness direction and its frequency varies from 0 Hz to 1000 Hz.

The temperature loaded on the smart beam is a uniform temperature. The temperature is considered at three values (233 K, 300 K and 423 K), which are constant temperatures on the upper and lower surfaces of the beam. Then, the tip displacement of the beam is attained as shown in Figure 5. From the results, it is seen that the natural frequencies are different with the different load conditions. In the adiabat environment, the natural frequencies in structural conditions are almost the same as in structural-electric conditions. However, in the thermal environment, the natural frequencies increase with the temperature increasing. Figure 5.
Harmonic analysis in different conditions.

sec.title: 4.2. Vibration control
sec.p:
Figure 6 shows the vibration control results of the tip displacement of the beam, (a), (b), (c) and (d) show the identification results in mechanical-electrical conditions, in mechanical-electrical-thermal (233 K) conditions, in mechanical-electrical-thermal (300 K) conditions and in mechanical-electrical-thermal (424 K) conditions respectively. The identification curve can fit very well the harmonic data in mechanical-electrical conditions. Figure 6.
The identifying results.

Figure 7 shows the free vibration control results of the tip displacement of the beam, (a), (b), (c) and (d) show the free vibration results in mechanical-electrical conditions, in mechanical-electrical-thermal (233 K) conditions, in mechanical-electrical-thermal (300 K) conditions and in mechanical-electrical-thermal (424 K) conditions with pole placement controllers and without controllers respectively. The blue lines represent the curves without controllers and the red dotted lines represent the curves with pole placement controllers. From Figure 7, the amplitudes of free vibration can be suppressed to a minimum in a short time. Figure 7.
The free vibration control results.
Finally, the control effects are visible from control results of Figure 7.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion and outlook
sec.p: From the above mechanical-electrical-thermal finite element theory, it can be seen that the mechanical-electrical-thermal FEM can tell clearly the transformation of the mechanical energy, electrical energy and thermal energy. The above identification method can identify the harmonic analysis data into the transfer functions from Figure 6. Then the transfer functions can be changed into a state space model to design the adaptive pole placement controller.
From Figure 7, the simulation results prove APPC is an effective control for vibration control.

In this paper are analyzed the dynamical properties of mechanical-electrical-thermal FEM in a linear model. Actually, the piezoelectric actuators have some nonlinear characteristics, such as hysteresis, saturation and so on. Furthermore, the controlled structures have nonlinear properties. So in the future work, the authors can work hard to study nonlinearities in piezoelectric materials and nonlinear vibration control.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant number 10972137).
